article:
'Odoh Diego Okenyodo' is a Nigerian writer, pharmacist, activist poet and
journalist, who was one of the founders of Kaduna Writers' League, KWL. He co-
edited CAMOUFLAGE: BEST OF CONTEMPORARY WRITING FROM NIGERIA, an anthology of
new Nigerian writers. The anthology included works by the most renowned
contemporary Nigerian writers such as Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie and Helon Habila.

His book of poems, intriguingly titled FROM A POEM TO ITS CREATOR, was released
in March 2009 by Hybun Publications International
[ http://www.hybun.com ] to high critical acclaim.

"Okenyodo's poetic exploration can be described as eclectic as he uses poetry to
make social comments, admonish and define poetry itself," a critic says of the
collection. [ http://234next.com/csp/cms/sites/Next/ArtsandCulture/Books/5413378-
147/story.csp ] Another says: "Going through Okenyodoâs poetry, you are
knocked into place." [ http://www.africanwriter.com/articles/379/1/From-a-Poem-to-its-Creator-
Meeting-Okenyodo/Page1.html ]

The poetry collection FROM A POEM TO ITS CREATOR was shortlisted for the
US$50,000 The Nigeria Prize for Literature in 2009, the year in which the
sponsors, Nigeria Liquefied Natural Gas Limited, did not award it.

Born on 2 December 1974 in St. Theresa's Hospital, Otukpo, Benue State, Nigeria,
Okenyodo attended the Ahmadu Bello University (ABU) Zaria where he led a
literary collective known as the Creative Writers' Club. As a result of his
activities in the club, he was expelled by the military administration of Major
General Mamman Kontagora, a military administrator who was foisted on the
institution in 1995 following a violent conflict in the university.

Okenyodo was reinstated in 2001, after three years battling the university
authorities in court and at various panels, including the famous "Oputa Panel".
During period out of the university, he lived on his writings and literary
performances.

In September 1999, the Weekly Trust engaged him as freelance correspondent,
which marked the formal beginning of a long-incubating career in journalism.
Earlier at the ABU Zaria, Okenyodo contributed to and edited some campus
magazines.

On the 23rd of June 2001, Okenyodo, working with colleaguesâSumaila Umaisha, Aba
Ejembi, Jerome Ajayiâfounded the Kaduna Writers' League. Also the Kaduna
Writers' League's chairman from inception to the year 2006, Okenyodo led the
editorial team of AFTER THE CURFEW, an anthology of creative writings drawn from
the League's five-year collection of a weekly bulletin known as "CROCODILE".

He was elected National Publicity Secretary of the Association of Nigerian
Authors (ANA) in November 2003, serving till November 2007. In December 2010, he
was appointed chairman of the local organising committee of the association's
30th anniversary convention scheduled to hold in Abuja in October 2011. Okenyodo
is a member of the Nigerian Institute of Public Relations (NIPR), Abuja, serving
in the publicity and public relations committee.

In 2006, Odoh Diego Okenyodo had relocated from Kaduna to work with the Abuja-
based Alliance for Credible Elections[ http://www.acenigeria.org ] as
Media Coordinator. From the alliance of civil society organisations, he got
employed with the Centre for Democracy and Development
(CDD)[ http://www.cddwestafrica.org ] as a senior programme officer
responsible for the organisation's communication.

In January 2009, in search of private-sector experience, he moved to CMC Connect
(Perception Managers)[ http://www.cmcconnect.com ] to head the
marketing communication firm's public affairs office based in Abuja. He is now
managing director of Isu Media Ltd, an Abuja-based public relations and
copyediting firm.

Odoh was part of the British Council/Lancaster University's Crossing Borders [http://www.crossingborders-
africanwriting.org] literary mentorship programme in 2005 and the InWent's
[http://www.gc21.inwent.org Global Campus] Measuring Democracy, Governance and
Human Rights course in Namibia (2008). He has worked on freelance-writer basis
for the BBC World Service Trust, ActionAid, Coalitions for Change, Centre for
Democracy and Development, Civil Society Legislative Advocacy Centre, etc.

Odoh is married to Oluwakemi.
